attributes.title: A Generation of Disappointed Princesses: An Exploratory Mixed Method Investigation into the relationship between the ‘Disney Ideal’ and Adult Mental Health in Millennial & Generation Z Population
attributes.description: An exploratory study investigating if common childhood narratives set unrealistic expectations of adult life and if there is evidence this may impact adult mental wellbeing.

q1.value: A Generation of Disappointed Princesses: An Exploratory Mixed-Method Investigation into the relationship between the ‘Disney Ideal’ and Adult Mental Health in Millennial & Generation Z Population

q3.value: An exploratory study investigating if common childhood narratives set unrealistic expectations of adult life and if there is evidence this may impact adult mental well-being.

q4.value:
1. The earlier an individual engages with the Disney Princess narrative the poorer the adult outcomes will be (as measured by HADS and SWL)
2. The more intensely an individual engages with the Disney Princess narrative the poorer the adult outcomes will be (as measured by HADS and SWL)
3. A preference for 'older'/'traditional' Disney Princess narratives will drive poorer adult outcomes will be (as measured by HADS and SWL)
4. Younger generations will have poorer adult outcomes will be (as measured by HADS and SWL)
5. The Disney Princess narrative forms unrealistic expectations in children, that when unrealised result in  poorer adult outcomes will be (as measured by HADS and SWL)

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A mixed approach conducted in two stages. The first stage will collect data via an online survey tool, with participants recruited through social media. These participants will be invited to participate in the second stage, interviews, with a small number being selected for interview N<10. Stage 2 participants will be selected based upon their indication of willingness to participate further and their responses to stage 1.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A mixed approach conducted in two stages. The first stage will collect data via an online survey tool, with participants (N>194) recruited through social media. These participants will be invited to participate in the second stage, interviews, with a small number being selected for interview N<10. Stage 2 participants will be selected based upon their indication of willingness to participate further and their responses to stage 1.

Adult participants will be recruited via social media platforms, as such the study will use opportunity sampling.

q13.value: N>194 for Stage 1 (quantitative) and N<10 for Stage 2 (qualitative)

q14.value: A sample size (N>194) has been selected using the G*Power tool (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) for multiple regression with 14 independent variables (although it is unlikely all 14 variables will be included simultaneously in the regression) . This was determined using conventions for alpha (α = 0.05), and medium effect size (d = 0.5) established by Cohen (1992). Medium effect size is recommended where existing research is unable to provide an established basis for calculation (Cohen, 1992).

question.value:
Participants will be assigned to a generational cohort (Preceding Generation, Baby Boomers, Generation X, Millennial, Generation Z).

Other demographics will be collected regarding SEN status, ethnicity, neurodiversity, gender identity and sexuality.


Survey Questions:

As a child, how old were you when you watched your first Disney Princess film (Age; I don't remember)

As a child, I watched Disney Princess films... (VAS 1-10, Never - All the Time)

As a child, I watched Disney Princess films... (VAS 1-10, Far less than my friends/siblings - Far more often than my friends/siblings)

As a child, Disney Princesses were an important part of my life (VAS 1-10, Not so much - Very much so)

Thinking back to when you were a child, please rank the Disney Princess films, with your favourite at the top and least favorite at the bottom (Disney Princess films released 1937-1998, N/a option for 'not seen')

As a child, I wanted to be one (or more) of the Disney Princesses (VAS 1-10, Not so much - Very much so)

As a child, I found watching Disney Princess films made me feel better (VAS 1-10, Not so much - Very much so)

As a child, Disney helped shape my expectations of adult life and/or romantic relationships (VAS 1-10, Not so much - Very much so)

Please rank the Disney Princess films, with your current favourite at the top and current least favourite at the bottom ((Disney Princess films released 1937-2019, N/a option for 'not seen')

As an adult, Disney Princesses still form an important part of my life (VAS 1-10, Not so much - Very much so)

As a child, I remember being (VAS 1-10, Mostly unhappy - Mostly happy)

As a child I believed my expectations of adult life were (VAS 1-10, Mostly unrealistic - Mostly realistic)

As a child, I believed my vision of the future was (VAS 1-10, Mostly pessimistic - Mostly optimistic)

As an adult, life has been generally (VAS 1-10, Harder than expected - Easier than expected)

As a child I always believed I would find 'the one' to be my 'forever love' (VAS 1-10, Strongly disagree - Strongly agree)

As a child, I believed finding 'the one' as my 'forever love' would make me happy (VAS 1-10, Strongly disagree - Strongly agree)

As a child, I believed I would need to grow through adversity in order to be happy (VAS 1-10, Strongly disagree - Strongly agree)

I believe I have experienced, or I have previously been diagnosed with depression and/or anxiety  (Anxiety, Depression, Anxiety and Depression, Neither, I'm Unsure/Unwilling to Answer)

HADS and SWL have also been embedded as indicative measures of adult mental well-being

We will use ANOVA and multiple regression for analysis of stage 1 (survey) data, which may lead to additional analysis depending upon these initial findings; thematic analysis of stage 2 (interview) data to provide additional insight.

q20.value: Using SPSS categorical variables such as Gender, Generation, Sexuality and SES will be recoded (see attached pilot test data file)

q22.value: Outliers will be included unless data violations compromise analysis assumption requirements.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete either the 'Disney experience' questions in stage 1, or the HADS/SWL they will not be included in the analysis (i.e. pairwise deletion).

summary.value:
PROTOCOLO - SCOPING REVIEW
Nurse Safety in the Management of Antineoplastic Therapy: Scoping Review
Objetivo
Identify and synthesize the scientific evidence on cancer nurse safety in the management of antineoplastic therapy.
Question Formulation
P (Population)  – Oncology Nursing.
C (Concept) –  Occupational Safety. 
C (Context) – Antineoplastic Agents.
The established research question was: what scientific evidence, in the context of antineoplastic agents, is available to ensure the occupational safety of the oncology nursing?
Inclusion criteria
Will be included: research; published in full in english, spanish and portuguese; dealing with nurse safety in the management of antineoplastic therapy, without time limit.
Exclusion criteria
Will be excluded: editorials, experience reports, theoretical essays and studies that address only patient safety. 
Data collect
•	Search for similar scoping reviews

•	A preliminary search was performed on the databases: CINAHL, PubMed, Literatura Latino-americana e do Caribe em Ciências da Saúde (LILACS), SCOPUS, Web of Science e biblioteca Cochrane.

•	Identification of descriptors and keywords
An initial search was conducted on the PubMed and CINAHL portal to identify the main descriptors and keywords used in studies that address the topic of interest from the combination of MeSH identified for the research mneumonic: ("Antineoplastic Agents" [Mesh] OR "Drug Therapy" [Mesh] OR "Chemotherapy, Adjuvant" [Mesh] OR "Induction Chemotherapy" [Mesh] OR "Consolidation Chemotherapy" OR "Maintenance Chemotherapy" [Mesh] OR "Medication Therapy Management" [Mesh] OR "Administration and Dosage" [Mesh]) AND ("Oncology Nursing"[Mesh]  OR “Nursing"[Mesh])  AND ("Safety"[Mesh] OR "Safety Management"[Mesh] OR "United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration"[Mesh] OR "National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (U.S.)"[Mesh] OR "Equipment Safety"[Mesh] OR "Personal Protective Equipment"[Mesh])

summary.value: This is a registration of stimuli and data for the project (files attached).

registration_responses.summary: This is a registration of stimuli and data for the project (files attached).

sample.value: 80 Participants will be recruited, this is based on Van Dessel & Vogt (2012) and funding restrictions.

analyses.value:
We will conduct an ANOVA with condition (emotion-related categorization task, gender- related categorization task), emergency congruency (emergency congruent, emergency incongruent) and sound (neutral, emergency-related).
This will be followed-up by contrasts per condition.

We will see how Prosocial personality (score on the Penner Questionnaire) relate to attentional bias scores.

outliers.value: Trials with errors on the dot probe task will be removed. Individual outliers (RTs shorter than 150 ms or larger than three standard deviations away from the participant’s individual means) for participants will be deleted. We will log-transform RTs if they are skewed.

dependent.value:
Attentional Bias towards people in an emergency and those who are not in need. A dot probe task will be used that measures reaction times to targets that replace an emergency scene or a non-emergency scene. Attentional trials will be preceded by neutral and emergency-related sounds. 

We will also test:

attributes.title: Protocol for an Endorsement of Ottawa ankle rules within outpatient physicians and physical therapists

q1.value: Protocol for an Endorsement of Ottawa ankle rules within outpatient physicians and physical therapists

q3.value:
Inversion or supination traumas are among the most common sports injuries of the lower extremity. To diagnose the severity of such injuries or corresponding concomitant injuries, the investigators have both clinical test procedures and imaging measures at their disposal. Due to the fact that imaging procedures are associated with increased costs, and that X-ray examinations, for example, involve exposure to X-rays, diagnostic guidelines have been established. One element of these guidelines is the so-called "Ottawa Ankle Rules" (OAR), which are intended to limit the performance of X-ray diagnostics. 
The OAR provide guidelines in the diagnosis of painful ankle joints. They are part of the AWMF guidelines for the examination of acute injuries to the outer ligament of the upper ankle. However, reviews such as those by Bachmann et al. show that the use of the OAR is not routinely applied in Germany. Current studies show that the consistent use of OAR could reduce the number of X-ray examinations by 30-40%. 
From the problem definition the question arises why the OAR are hardly implemented in Germany. Therefore, the question will be investigated as to whether doctors are aware of the contents of the OAR or whether they consider them to be clinically relevant. On the other hand, it will be investigated how relevant doctors and physiotherapists regard imaging diagnostics in the examination of patients with lateral ankle pain.  In addition, it will be analysed whether there are differences in the observance of the OAR between physicians and physiotherapists in terms of diagnostics.
The work starts at the point where it seems that patients with supination traumas are too often subjected to X-ray examinations. Due to the health risks that can arise from too frequent exposure to X-rays, a reduction of radiation exposure in these patients is possible by implementing the OAR in clinical diagnostics. 
On the other hand, the analysis is used by physicians and therapists to investigate possible differences in the planning and approach of clinical diagnostics. 
The OAR were established in 1992 and are described in the current guidelines of the German Society for Trauma Surgery (DGU) from the year 2017. There is evidence that ankle fractures can be almost 100% excluded by using the OAR. Nevertheless, current studies show that diagnostics by means of X-ray diagnostics is used in almost all patients with suspected fractures in the area of the upper ankle joint. There are also tendencies that imaging diagnostics are used, but other concomitant injuries, such as syndesmosis injuries, are overlooked.  The question that cannot be answered in these studies is why the OAR are rarely used and whether they are regularly used by the clinical examination of physiotherapists in Germany. 
The aim of the thesis is to investigate the assessment of the clinical relevance of the contents of the OAR by physicians and therapists.

q4.value:
H1: The contents of the "Ottawa Ankle Rules" are recognized as clinically relevant by physicians working as outpatients in Germany.
H2: The contents of the "Ottawa Ankle Rules" are recognised as clinically relevant by physiotherapists working as outpatients in Germany.
H3: There are no differences in knowledge of the Ottawa Ankle Rules between medical and therapeutic examination.
H4: There are differences regarding the recognition of the clinical relevance of the Ottawa Ankle Rules in the regions of Southern, Northern, Western and Eastern Germany. 
H5: The professional experience of outpatient physicians in Germany has an influence on the recognition of the clinical relevance of the Ottawa Ankle Rules.
H6: The professional experience of physiotherapists working as outpatients in Germany has an influence on the assessment of the clinical relevance of the Ottawa Ankle Rules.
H7: Physicians working in outpatient clinics in Germany assess the testing of syndesmosis tibiofibularis as clinically relevant in the clinical examination of acute injuries of the upper ankle joint.
H8: Physiotherapists working in outpatient clinics in Germany consider the testing of syndesmosis tibiofibularis clinically relevant in the clinical examination of acute injuries of the upper ankle joint.
H9: Outpatient physicians in Germany consider testing of the anterior drawer to be clinically relevant in the clinical examination of acute injuries of the upper ankle joint.
H10: Physiotherapists working in outpatient clinics in Germany consider testing of the front drawer to be clinically relevant in the clinical examination of acute injuries of the upper ankle joint.
H11: Physicians working in outpatient clinics in Germany assess the evaluation of imaging procedures in the clinical examination of acute injuries of the upper ankle joint as clinically relevant.
H12: The clinical acceptance of the "Ottawa Ankle Rules" has an influence on the assessment of the relevance of the evaluation of imaging procedures.
H13: There is an influence of the professional experience of outpatient physicians in Germany on the evaluation of the clinical relevance of imaging procedures. 
H14: Outpatient physicians and physiotherapists in Germany assess the testing of pressure pain sensitivity of the proximal fibula as clinically relevant in the clinical investigation of acute injuries of the upper ankle.

question.value:
The study of the hypotheses takes place in the field of quantitative research. Bortz and Döring describe that there are different methods of qualitative social research to operationalize a research object. These include oral and written questioning. One form of the written survey is the analysis by means of a questionnaire. According to Schnell et al. the aim of quantitative research is "to test theories that are suitable for the formulation of generally valid statements and regularities" (Schnell et al. 2005: 7). 
In the present study a non-experimental design in the form of a questionnaire is used. In addition, the study has the research design of a cross-sectional study, since the data were collected at a specific point in time or in a specific period of time. 
Furthermore, inclusion criteria were defined, which should be considered when the study participants answer the questions. On the one hand, the age for the consideration of the questions was determined to be between 18 and 65 years. These criteria were shown within the explanation of the questionnaire. Inclusion criteria were also defined for the respondents themselves. Thus, it was determined that the respondents must be employed at the time of the survey and must have sufficient knowledge of the German language to participate in the study. These two criteria were already checked during the recruitment of the study participants.

question.value:
The data collection took place in the form of an e-mail, in which the questionnaires were sent electronically to the participating practices. This form of the questionnaire is to be counted towards a written survey. It was used because the size of the sample can be larger than with other forms of survey, such as telephone surveys or oral (face-to-face) interviews, with the same amount of resources (cf. Schnell et al. 1999: 335 ff.). Furthermore, written surveys increase the anonymity of the survey and reduce the time pressure when answering the questionnaire (cf. Kirchhoff et al. 2000).
In order to keep the workload for the participating practices as low as possible, a so-called "Microsoft Office" developer tool was used to answer the questions in the questionnaire file. This made it possible to fill out the questionnaire directly on the computer. For this purpose, a box was added to each answer option of the 9 questions, which was marked with a cross by clicking on it. The respondents were asked to do this for each question. Afterwards, the questionnaire should only be saved and sent back to the investigator-in-charge by e-mail.
The survey period was set to 4 weeks. In the run-up to the survey, all participants were interviewed by telephone or e-mail about their participation in the study. All questionnaires were sent to the participating practices on the same day. After two weeks, the practices were contacted by telephone or e-mail whose questionnaires had not yet been returned to the survey director. The same procedure was carried out at the beginning of the fourth week of the given period.   
The completed questionnaires were then coded and the results of the survey were transferred to an Excel spreadsheet. In order to guarantee the objectivity of the analysis, the coding and transfer was carried out by an independent person. Therefore the results can be considered blinded. On the other hand, this step increases data protection. 
Inclusion criteria were defined for the recruitment of study participants. For the participating physiotherapies, care was taken to ensure that "manual therapy" or "sports physiotherapy" was included in the range of services offered by the corresponding facilities. Care was taken to ensure that the participating medical practices were general practitioners, sports physicians or orthopaedic specialists. 
It was also determined that only outpatient practices would be contacted for the study. Hospitals and rehabilitation clinics were excluded because it was difficult to establish contact with these institutions and it was often not possible to contact a corresponding contact person in the institution directly.  
The aim of recruitment was to recruit a total of one hundred outpatient physiotherapy practices for participation in the study, and one hundred outpatient medical practices. In order to achieve a representation of the results for all of Germany, Germany was divided into 4 regions. A distinction was made between Southern Germany, Eastern Germany, Northern Germany and Western Germany. The aim of this measure was also to identify possible local differences in the application of the OAR. In southern Germany, practices from the federal states of Bavaria and Baden- Württemberg were contacted. The area of eastern Germany included the federal states of Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Brandenburg and Berlin. Northern Germany was to be represented by the federal states of Bremen, Hamburg, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, Lower Saxony and Schleswig-Holstein. The region of West Germany included the federal states of Hesse, North Rhine-Westphalia, Rhineland-Palatinate and Saarland. An attempt was made to recruit twenty-five medical practices and physiotherapy practices per region or area. In addition, the aim was to have at least three medical and physiotherapy practices in each state. 
The participants were also asked to sign a declaration of consent to participate in the study and to return this form scanned to the study director. A standardized declaration of the Ethics Committee of the German Sport University in Cologne was used.

q13.value: The aim of recruitment was to recruit a total of one hundred outpatient physiotherapy practices to participate in the study, and one hundred outpatient medical practices.

question.value:
The evaluation of each of the nine questions was recorded. The respondents were able to rate the relevance of each question between 1 (not relevant) and 9 (very relevant). 
In addition, personal data was collected. The professional experience, the prevalence of acute ankle injuries in daily practice, the profession or specialty of the participants, and the region in Germany in which the respondents work in the outpatient sector were recorded.

Descriptively, the respective median value as well as the minimum and maximum characteristic values were given in addition to the determination of the respective mean values of the parameters surveyed with the corresponding standard deviation. The mean value and the median describe "the position of the observed values on a numerical line and are therefore defined [as] position parameters" (Lehn & Wegmann 1992: 80). The minimum value, on the other hand, like the maximum value, is called the "dispersion parameter" and forms the value of the range, which is to be regarded as the "difference between minimum and maximum" (Lehn & Wegmann 1992: 23). The standard deviation is also a measure of dispersion and is to be regarded as "a measure of the spread of the values of a characteristic around its mean value" (Walser 2011: 11). The basis for the calculation of the standard deviation is the variance. This value characterises the distribution of values around the mean value and is "the square of the standard deviation" (Walser 2011: 13). The standard deviation is then calculated as root of the variance. The lower and first quartile as well as the upper and third quartile were also determined for each data series. Both are further measures of location, which are less sensitive to extreme values. The range between the upper and lower quartiles is referred to as the quartile distance. This was also determined for each of the 9 questions asked in the questionnaire. The quartile distance describes the range of the middle fifty percent of a data series. The quartile distance is also considered less sensitive to extreme values. 
In the field of inductive statistics, different procedures were applied depending on the hypothesis. In order to make the knowledge of the OAR comparable, questions one and three to six were combined with the corresponding evaluations per question. The sum of these 5 questions could be used to assess the knowledge of the OAR. It was determined that a minimum value of 35 had to be reached in order to assume knowledge of the OAR. The minimum value of 35 was set because this corresponded to an average score of 7. A score of 7 should be considered as the minimum value of the class, which is considered to be very relevant and should be taken into account for the clinical examination. In order to compare the knowledge of the OAR among physicians and physiotherapists (hypothesis 3), a mean value comparison of the two groups was carried out. Since the evaluation of the questions should be considered as ordinal data, no "t-test" could be used. Since the sample survey was carried out individually in each case, it is an independent type of sample survey. Since the mean value comparison of physicians and physiotherapists involves exactly 2 study groups, the "Mann-Whitney-U-Test" was used. 
The mean value comparison was different for the analysis of the application of the OAR in the different regions of Germany (Hypothesis 4). The regions of Southern, Western, Eastern and Northern Germany were compared. For this purpose the mean value was calculated from the sum of the 5 questions on the contents of the OAR using the "H-test according to Kruskal and Valais". 
A correlation analysis was carried out to investigate the influence of professional experience on the assessment of the relevance of the OAR or the relevance of imaging procedures. Hypotheses 5, 6 and 14 were therefore analysed with the Spearman rank correlation coefficient. This could be used because the survey produced ordinally scaled data. Hypothesis 12, which relates to the influence of knowledge of the OAR on the assessment of the relevance of imaging procedures, was also calculated with the Spearman rank correlation coefficient

registration_responses.q17.question:
The evaluation of each of the nine questions was recorded. The respondents were able to rate the relevance of each question between 1 (not relevant) and 9 (very relevant). 
In addition, personal data was collected. The professional experience, the prevalence of acute ankle injuries in daily practice, the profession or specialty of the participants, and the region in Germany in which the respondents work in the outpatient sector were recorded.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Descriptively, the respective median value as well as the minimum and maximum characteristic values were given in addition to the determination of the respective mean values of the parameters surveyed with the corresponding standard deviation. The mean value and the median describe "the position of the observed values on a numerical line and are therefore defined [as] position parameters" (Lehn & Wegmann 1992: 80). The minimum value, on the other hand, like the maximum value, is called the "dispersion parameter" and forms the value of the range, which is to be regarded as the "difference between minimum and maximum" (Lehn & Wegmann 1992: 23). The standard deviation is also a measure of dispersion and is to be regarded as "a measure of the spread of the values of a characteristic around its mean value" (Walser 2011: 11). The basis for the calculation of the standard deviation is the variance. This value characterises the distribution of values around the mean value and is "the square of the standard deviation" (Walser 2011: 13). The standard deviation is then calculated as root of the variance. The lower and first quartile as well as the upper and third quartile were also determined for each data series. Both are further measures of location, which are less sensitive to extreme values. The range between the upper and lower quartiles is referred to as the quartile distance. This was also determined for each of the 9 questions asked in the questionnaire. The quartile distance describes the range of the middle fifty percent of a data series. The quartile distance is also considered less sensitive to extreme values. 
In the field of inductive statistics, different procedures were applied depending on the hypothesis. In order to make the knowledge of the OAR comparable, questions one and three to six were combined with the corresponding evaluations per question. The sum of these 5 questions could be used to assess the knowledge of the OAR. It was determined that a minimum value of 35 had to be reached in order to assume knowledge of the OAR. The minimum value of 35 was set because this corresponded to an average score of 7. A score of 7 should be considered as the minimum value of the class, which is considered to be very relevant and should be taken into account for the clinical examination. In order to compare the knowledge of the OAR among physicians and physiotherapists (hypothesis 3), a mean value comparison of the two groups was carried out. Since the evaluation of the questions should be considered as ordinal data, no "t-test" could be used. Since the sample survey was carried out individually in each case, it is an independent type of sample survey. Since the mean value comparison of physicians and physiotherapists involves exactly 2 study groups, the "Mann-Whitney-U-Test" was used. 
The mean value comparison was different for the analysis of the application of the OAR in the different regions of Germany (Hypothesis 4). The regions of Southern, Western, Eastern and Northern Germany were compared. For this purpose the mean value was calculated from the sum of the 5 questions on the contents of the OAR using the "H-test according to Kruskal and Valais". 
A correlation analysis was carried out to investigate the influence of professional experience on the assessment of the relevance of the OAR or the relevance of imaging procedures. Hypotheses 5, 6 and 14 were therefore analysed with the Spearman rank correlation coefficient. This could be used because the survey produced ordinally scaled data. Hypothesis 12, which relates to the influence of knowledge of the OAR on the assessment of the relevance of imaging procedures, was also calculated with the Spearman rank correlation coefficient

attributes.title: Perspectives on Gender Differences and Effect on Agency and Bias Confrontation

summary.value:
Participants
Participants will be recruited via subordinate-supervisor pairs from various organizations recruited using the snowball sampling methodology. Undergraduate students attending a large university in the United States will be invited to identify a working adult (subordinate) and their supervisor to participate in two separate online surveys. The snowball sampling methodology has been successfully used in previous studies (e.g., Grant & Mayer, 2009; Mayer, Thau, Workman, Van Dijke, & De Cremer, 2012; Mitchell & Ambrose, 2012). Students participating in the study will be compensated with extra credit.

Procedures
This study will utilize slightly revised gender messages conveying gender differences with or without educating about the sources of these differences (see Files). In this study we will follow up with dependent variables assessing participants identification with their gender identity and behavioral intentions to advocate for women. The basic study design is as follows:
1.	Participants will read an information sheet and continue with the study to acknowledge their consent.
2.	After consenting to participate, participants will be told to imagine they work at the company whose website they will view on the next page. Then, they will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions:
a. Gender awareness condition: In this condition, participants will read a mock-up company website describing the existence of gender differences and their role in the workplace.
b. Gender education condition: In this condition, participants will read a mock-up company website describing the existence and source of gender differences and their role in the workplace.
3.	Next, participants will respond to the following questions:
1.	Please consider the following statistics: In 2012, women made up approximately 40% of professional and managerial positions in the United States, but they only made up 4% of Executive Officers and 16.1% of board members of Fortune 500 companies. Multiple factors may contribute to these outcomes. What do you believe are the top five most important factors explaining differences in the numbers of men and women in corporate leadership positions? Please rank in order from most i1mportant to least important.
1.	Sexist attitudes among current execs and board members (1) stereotypes/prejudice 
2.	Women are likely to shoulder a larger percenter of the family responsibilities (2) structural inequality
3.	Women are less likely to want these types of positions (3) personal attribution (i.e., participant holds stereotypical beliefs)
4.	Women are less likely to have the necessary personal attributes (e.g., confidence) (4) personal attribution (i.e., participant holds stereotypical beliefs)
5.	Women are less likely have access to the necessary mentorship/sponsorship opportunities (5) structural inequality
2.	People vary in how important their group memberships are. How important is your gender to you? Rate the following items on the scale below. (1 – strongly agree, 7 – strongly disagree)
1.	I have a strong sense of connection to other people of my gender
2.	My gender is an important reflection of who I am.
3.	Think about the next 10 years of your experience in the workplace. How likely would you be to engage in the following activities? (1 – not at all likely, 7 – extremely likely)
1.	Be part of a formal mentorship program for women. 
2.	Informally mentor women at my organization.
3.	Advocate for promoting more highly qualified women at my organization.
4.	Promote the professional development of women.
4.	Think about how gender has or has not mattered for your experience in the workplace. If you were asked to give advice to a recent hire at your company taking gender into account, what would you say? (Open-ended)
4.	Then, participants will complete two 1-item manipulation checks assessing gender essentialism and gender education.
5.	Lastly, all participants will respond to demographic measures (i.e. gender, race, employment status, etc.).
Hypotheses
For our dependent variables, we predict that, compared to women in the gender-awareness condition, women in the gender education condition will be more likely to: 1) rank structural inequality and/or sexism as more important in explaining gender differences in leadership, 2) identify highly with their gender identity and 3) report higher intentions to advocate for women. We do not predict that men’s responses to our dependent variables will vary significantly across our experimental conditions. Additionally, we predict that participants in the gender-awareness condition will show greater gender essentialism than participants in the gender-education condition. Finally, we predict that participants in the gender-education condition will show greater scores on our gender education manipulation check than participants in the gender-awareness condition. 
Exploratory Analyses
In addition, we will use thematic coding to code participants’ open-ended responses. We theorize that women in the gender education condition, compared to those in the gender awareness condition, may provide advice that references more structural accounts of gender differences.

q1.value: Effects of a Six-Months Therapy Combining Schema Therapy with Exposure and Response Prevention for Patients with Chronic Anxiety and Comorbid Personality Disorders: an Explorative Study.

q2.value: Nancy Peeters, Drs. B. van Passel, Prof. Dr. G. J. Hendriks, Julie Krans

q3.value:
Anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorders (OCD) are among the most common mental health issues worldwide (Ghaedi, Tavoli, Bakhtiari, Melyani, & Sahragard, 2010). Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is the preferred treatment for patients with anxiety disorders or OCD. Even though CBT is effective for most patients, 30-40% of the patients do not respond to CBT (Durham, Chambers, MacDonald, Power, & Major, 2003). For those patients, often no alternative evidence-based psychological treatments are available. Therefore, new evidence-based therapies need to be developed.
A new treatment program was developed for patients with an anxiety disorder or OCD and comorbid personality disorder: ‘SCHerp’ aims to reduce anxiety symptoms by combining and integrating schema therapy (SCH) with exposure and response prevention (erp). Previous observational research investigating the effectivity of SCHerp showed that 58.2% of the patients improved after treatment (Appel, Pranger, Stappenbelt, Burke, Van Passel, & Krans, submitted for publication). Although these results are promising, the SCHerp program can still be improved. 
The aim of this study is to evaluate, for each participant, the effectiveness of the SCHerp program in reducing both psychological malfunction and severity of disorder specific symptoms. In addition, we aim to evaluate changes in adaptive and maladaptive schema modes, and in implicit avoidance tendencies during the SCHerp program. Lastly, we aim to identify and generate hypotheses about periods within SCHerp with the highest gains (e.g. largest decline in anxiety/OCD symptoms).

q4.value:
With this explorative study we aim to generate hypotheses about the effectiveness and underlying working mechanisms of the SCHerp program.  

Our first objective is to evaluate, for each participant, the effectiveness of the SCHerp program. Accordance with our previous findings, we expect to find that this treatment is effective in reducing psychological malfunction for at least half of the patients.

Our secondary objectives are:
(1) Evaluate changes in adaptive and maladaptive schema modes during the SCHerp program. Matching the goal of schema therapy, we expect a decline in maladaptive modes and an increase in adaptive modes after treatment. 

(2) Identify and generate hypotheses about periods within SCHerp with the highest gains
(e.g. largest decline in anxiety/OCD symptoms). 

(3) Evaluate changes in implicit avoidance tendencies during the SCHerp program.

Objectives 2.2 and 2.3 are non-directional explorative analyses.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is an observational study with a nonconcurrent multiple baseline design (Carr, 2015). This design is suitable to demonstrate that changes occurred as a result of SCHerp instead of mere time. A standard RCT is not suitable nor feasible given the small and specific target group (Onghena, 2005). Furthermore, including a control group would be ethically complicated in this population, as it is difficult to select a suitable comparison. That is, guideline treatment was previously unsuccessful in these patients, often even with multiple attempts, and a waiting list would keep them from necessary treatment for 6 months more than usual. Additional practical and ethical advantages of a multiple baseline design are that (1) the design requires fewer participants and (2) it has an increased power because participants act as their own control (Arntz, Sofi, van Breukelen, 2013). The study will have a duration of 10.5 months. In this period, we will assess 2 cohorts of 4 SCHerp patients each (total number of patients N = 8). Each cohort will receive the 6 months SCHerp protocol with 3 months overlap (half-open group). Before start of treatment, participants will be assessed during a baseline period which will be randomized between 3, 4, 5 and 6 baseline assessments before start of treatment, falling within the natural waitlist period. From first baseline assessment to end of program 6 months later, each participant will be assessed on a weekly basis. This results in 29 to 32 assessments per participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
In order to be eligible to participate in this study, participants must meet all of the following criteria: 
• Participant in the SCHerp program. 
• Age 18+ years. 
• Fluent in Dutch. 
• Able to give informed consent. 

Exclusion criteria are not applicable.

The treating therapist will ask all 8 patients, scheduled to start the SCHerp program at respectively April and July 2020, if they allow a researcher to contact them for research. Patients open to research will, 12 weeks before the start of their therapy, be contacted by telephone by the researcher concerning the research. During this first contact, the researcher will explain the background and goals of the study. If patients are interested, they will receive the information letter about the research via mail. A week after this first contact, patients will be contacted by phone or mail to provide answers to any further questions and ask whether they are interested in participation. Interested patients will, in a few days, receive an email with the start date of their baseline measurements. Start dates are pre-randomized between 3, 4, 5 or 6 weeks before the start of the therapy. Participants need to sign the informed consent on the first measurement day, before start of measurements. 
During the 6-month therapy, the measurements will take place at the treatment center on the morning of the first treatment day of the week (e.g., treatment starts on Tuesday at 10 am, and testing is scheduled on that day at 9 am). Measurements during baseline are also preferably assessed on the same morning at the treatment center, but if not feasible, this can be assessed more flexible at home/online. From the start of the baseline to the end of therapy, participants will be assessed weekly. Every assessment will take approximately one hour. Within these assessments, each participant has to fill in several questionnaires and tests on a computer (see Measured variables for details).

Participants will receive a monetary compensation for their time of 15 euros per assessment. This results in a total monetary compensation of 435 to 480 euros per participant (depending on the duration of the baseline) when all assessments are completed. If participants need to travel for baseline assessments, they will receive 0.19 euro/km travel reimbursement.

q13.value: In this study we will include 8 patients with chronic anxiety disorders and/or OCD with comorbid (cluster C) personality disorder who are on the waiting list to start the SCHerp program.

q14.value: To the best of our knowledge, there is no procedure for performing a power analysis for a nonconcurrent baseline design. Nevertheless, statistical experts have shown that this design has a power of 0.8 with a minimum sample size of N = 4 and 20 measurements per participant (Onghena, 2005). To reach sufficient power for this study, and to handle possible dropouts, we aim to include two cohorts of 4 patients each.

question.value:
In this study we will measure the following variables. All questionnaires and tests will be in Dutch. 

(1)	Psychological malfunction (assessed with the Outcome Questionnaire (OQ-45)). 
•	The Outcome Questionnaire-45 (OQ-45; Lambert et al., 1996; Jong et al., 2008) is a 45-item self-report questionnaire assessing psychological malfunction and is frequently used to investigate treatment results (Hatfield & Ogles, 2004). This questionnaire consists of three subscales: (1) symptom distress, (2) problems in interpersonal relations and (3) problems in social role performance. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (never) to 4 (always). The OQ-45 has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.93 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.79 (Jong et al., 2008). 
(2)	Severity of disorder specific symptoms (depending on the diagnosis assessed with the Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale, the Panic Disorder Severity Scale, the Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale, the Penn State Worry Questionnaire, The Whiteley Index or the Posttraumatic Symptom Scale).
•	Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale (Self-Report version) (YBOCS-SR; Goodman et al., 1989a; Steketee, Frost, & Bogart, 1996) is a 10-item self-report questionnaire assessing the severity of obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Items are rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 4 (extreme). The Y-BOCS-SR has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.78-0.89 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.88 (Rapp, Bergman, Piacentini, & Mcguire, 2016). 
•	Panic Disorder Severity Scale (Self-Report version) (PDSS-SR; Houck, Spiegel, Shear, & Rucci, 2002) is a 7- item self-report questionnaire used to assess panic disorder severity. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from (0) none to (4) extreme. The PDSS-SR has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.92 and a testretest Person’s correlation of 0.81 (Houck et al., 2002).
•	Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale (LSAS; Liebowitz, 1987) is a 24-item self-report questionnaire used to assess social anxiety and social avoidance severity. Questions can be divided into two subscales: (1) social situations and (2) situations in which one has to perform. Every item has to be rated twice to assess both their frequency of avoidance and to assess the anxiety that the situation evokes. Items about anxiety and avoidance are both rated on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (none) to 3 (very much) and from 0 (never) to 3 (almost always), respectively. The LSAS has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.95 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.83 (Baker, Heinrichs, Kim, Hofmann, 2001). 
•	Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer, Miller, Metzger, & Borkovec, 1990) is used for participants with generalized anxiety disorder. The PSWQ is a 16-item self-report questionnaire used to assess worry. This questionnaire consists of four subscales: (1) occurrence, (2) intrusiveness, (3) pervasiveness and (4) other characterizing features of an individual’s experience with worry. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all typical) to 5 (very typical of me). The PSWQ has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.93 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.92 (Meyer et al., 1990). 
•	Whiteley Index (WI; Pilowski, 1967; Speckens et al., 1996) is used for patients with hypochondria. The WI is a 7-item self-report questionnaire assessing hypochondriacal worries and beliefs. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very bad). The WI has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.73 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.66 (Hedman et al., 2015). 
•	Posttraumatic Symptom Scale (Self-Report version) (PSS-SR; Foa, Riggs, Dancu, & Rothbaum, 1997; Engelhard, Arntz, & Van den Hout, 2007) is a 17-item self-report questionnaire assessing PTSD symptoms. This questionnaire consists of 3 subscales: (1) hyperarousal, (2) re-experiencing and (3) avoidance. Items are rated on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (never) to 3 (5 times per week or more). The PSS-SR has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.92 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.83 (Foa et al., 1997). 
(3)	Adaptive and maladaptive modes (assessed with the short Schema Mode Inventory (SMI)).
•	The short Schema Mode Inventory (SMI; Young et al., 2007) is a 124-item self-report questionnaire assessing the presence of the following 14 modes: Vulnerable Child, Angry Child, Enraged Child, Impulsive Child, Undisciplined Child, Happy Child, Compliant Surrenderer, Detached Protector, Detached Self-Soother, Self-Aggrandizer, Bully and Attack, Punitive Parent, Demanding Parent, and Healthy Adult. These modes can be categorized in an adaptive adult mode (healthy adult), an adaptive child (happy child) and maladaptive modes (remaining 12 modes; Schaap, Chakhssi, & Westerhof, 2016). Items are rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never or hardly ever) to 6 (always). The SMI has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.87 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.84 (Lobberstael, 2010).
(4)	Implicit avoidance tendencies (assessed with the Approach Avoindance Task (AAT)).
•	The Approach Avoidance Task (AAT; Rinck & Becker, 2006) is used to assess implicit avoidance tendencies. In this task, participants are presented with stimuli on a computer screen and instructed to use a joystick to either pull the stimuli towards them or to push the stimuli away. Pulling the joystick will make the picture bigger (approach) while pushing will make the picture smaller (avoid). To assess avoidance tendencies, reaction times in the pull condition are compares to reaction times in the corresponding push condition. An avoidance tendency is reflected when the response time in the push condition is shorter than in the pull condition. In this study, the individual stimuli will be adjusted to the specified anxiety disorder and fears of the participant. The advantage of this task is that it is robust against social desirability (Heuer, Rinck, Becker, 2007).

Primary Objective: Evaluate, for each participant, the effectiveness of the SCHerp program.
Simulation Modelling Analysis (SMA) will be used to test the effectiveness of the SCHerp program for each participant. This method is developed to analyze autocorrelated time-series data with less than 30 measurements per phase and offers good protection against Type-I error while providing adequate power to detect real effects within the short time-series (Borckardt, 2006). As dependent variables (quantitative) we will use the total scores from the OQ- 45, YBOCS, PDSS, LSAS, PSWQ, WI and/or ‘PTSS klachtenschaal’ questionnaires. 

Secondary objective 1: Evaluate changes in adaptive and maladaptive schema modes during the SCHerp program.
The presence of adaptive and maladaptive schema modes will be assessed by the SMI. SMI scores will be categorized into three different scores: (1) adaptive adult mode, (2) adaptive child mode and (3) maladaptive modes. SMA will be used to analyze changes in adaptive and maladaptive schema modes throughout the therapy. All analyses are done for each participant individually. 

Secondary objective 2: Identify and generate hypotheses about periods within SCHerp
with the highest gains (i.e. strongest decline in complains).
For these analyses we make use of figures generated by the SMA of primary objective 1,
representing psychological malfunction and disorder-specific complains throughout the
therapy.
Using visual inspection, we will identify the periods within SCHerp with the highest gains
in decreasing psychological malfunction and/or disorder-specific complains. Sequentially
we will formulate hypotheses about possible underlying mechanisms, for which we can
use data from the secondary objectives as well. These hypotheses will then be tested in
further studies.

Secondary objective 3: Evaluate changes in implicit avoidance tendencies during the
SCHerp program.
Implicit avoidance tendencies are measured with the AAT and will be calculated by
subtracting the median reaction time in the pull condition from the median reaction time in
the corresponding push condition (fear-push minus fear-pull and neutral-push minus
neutral-pull). A negative value represents stronger avoidance than approach tendencies
(Heuer et al., 2007). SMA will be used to analyze changes in implicit avoidance tendencies throughout the therapy. All analyses are done for each participant individually.

q21.value: We will use the standard two-tailed p<.05 criteria for determining if the SMA test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. Bonferroni correction will be used to correct for multiple comparisons.

q23.value: Missing data will be checked for randomness. Random missing data points will be handled by multiple imputations (Ji, Chow, Schermerhorn, Jacobson, & Cummings, 2018).

q24.value: Using linear regression, we will exporatory look for relations between the presence of the different schema modes before therapy and decline of complaints during therapy. For example, in the SCHerp programme, different schema modes are focused on in each week of the therapy. It is possible that higher gains can be detected if the thematic mode matches the most prominent schema mode of the patient. Bonferroni correction will be used to correct for multiple comparisons.

registration_responses.q23: Missing data will be checked for randomness. Random missing data points will be handled by multiple imputations (Ji, Chow, Schermerhorn, Jacobson, & Cummings, 2018).
registration_responses.q24: Using linear regression, we will exporatory look for relations between the presence of the different schema modes before therapy and decline of complaints during therapy. For example, in the SCHerp programme, different schema modes are focused on in each week of the therapy. It is possible that higher gains can be detected if the thematic mode matches the most prominent schema mode of the patient. Bonferroni correction will be used to correct for multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is an observational study with a nonconcurrent multiple baseline design (Carr, 2015). This design is suitable to demonstrate that changes occurred as a result of SCHerp instead of mere time. A standard RCT is not suitable nor feasible given the small and specific target group (Onghena, 2005). Furthermore, including a control group would be ethically complicated in this population, as it is difficult to select a suitable comparison. That is, guideline treatment was previously unsuccessful in these patients, often even with multiple attempts, and a waiting list would keep them from necessary treatment for 6 months more than usual. Additional practical and ethical advantages of a multiple baseline design are that (1) the design requires fewer participants and (2) it has an increased power because participants act as their own control (Arntz, Sofi, van Breukelen, 2013). The study will have a duration of 10.5 months. In this period, we will assess 2 cohorts of 4 SCHerp patients each (total number of patients N = 8). Each cohort will receive the 6 months SCHerp protocol with 3 months overlap (half-open group). Before start of treatment, participants will be assessed during a baseline period which will be randomized between 3, 4, 5 and 6 baseline assessments before start of treatment, falling within the natural waitlist period. From first baseline assessment to end of program 6 months later, each participant will be assessed on a weekly basis. This results in 29 to 32 assessments per participant.
registration_responses.q12.question:
In order to be eligible to participate in this study, participants must meet all of the following criteria: 
• Participant in the SCHerp program. 
• Age 18+ years. 
• Fluent in Dutch. 
• Able to give informed consent. 

Exclusion criteria are not applicable.

The treating therapist will ask all 8 patients, scheduled to start the SCHerp program at respectively April and July 2020, if they allow a researcher to contact them for research. Patients open to research will, 12 weeks before the start of their therapy, be contacted by telephone by the researcher concerning the research. During this first contact, the researcher will explain the background and goals of the study. If patients are interested, they will receive the information letter about the research via mail. A week after this first contact, patients will be contacted by phone or mail to provide answers to any further questions and ask whether they are interested in participation. Interested patients will, in a few days, receive an email with the start date of their baseline measurements. Start dates are pre-randomized between 3, 4, 5 or 6 weeks before the start of the therapy. Participants need to sign the informed consent on the first measurement day, before start of measurements. 
During the 6-month therapy, the measurements will take place at the treatment center on the morning of the first treatment day of the week (e.g., treatment starts on Tuesday at 10 am, and testing is scheduled on that day at 9 am). Measurements during baseline are also preferably assessed on the same morning at the treatment center, but if not feasible, this can be assessed more flexible at home/online. From the start of the baseline to the end of therapy, participants will be assessed weekly. Every assessment will take approximately one hour. Within these assessments, each participant has to fill in several questionnaires and tests on a computer (see Measured variables for details).

Participants will receive a monetary compensation for their time of 15 euros per assessment. This results in a total monetary compensation of 435 to 480 euros per participant (depending on the duration of the baseline) when all assessments are completed. If participants need to travel for baseline assessments, they will receive 0.19 euro/km travel reimbursement.
registration_responses.q16.question: Not applicable (observational study).
registration_responses.q17.question:
In this study we will measure the following variables. All questionnaires and tests will be in Dutch. 

(1)	Psychological malfunction (assessed with the Outcome Questionnaire (OQ-45)). 
•	The Outcome Questionnaire-45 (OQ-45; Lambert et al., 1996; Jong et al., 2008) is a 45-item self-report questionnaire assessing psychological malfunction and is frequently used to investigate treatment results (Hatfield & Ogles, 2004). This questionnaire consists of three subscales: (1) symptom distress, (2) problems in interpersonal relations and (3) problems in social role performance. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (never) to 4 (always). The OQ-45 has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.93 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.79 (Jong et al., 2008). 
(2)	Severity of disorder specific symptoms (depending on the diagnosis assessed with the Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale, the Panic Disorder Severity Scale, the Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale, the Penn State Worry Questionnaire, The Whiteley Index or the Posttraumatic Symptom Scale).
•	Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale (Self-Report version) (YBOCS-SR; Goodman et al., 1989a; Steketee, Frost, & Bogart, 1996) is a 10-item self-report questionnaire assessing the severity of obsessive-compulsive symptoms. Items are rated on a 5-point scale ranging from 0 (no symptoms) to 4 (extreme). The Y-BOCS-SR has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.78-0.89 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.88 (Rapp, Bergman, Piacentini, & Mcguire, 2016). 
•	Panic Disorder Severity Scale (Self-Report version) (PDSS-SR; Houck, Spiegel, Shear, & Rucci, 2002) is a 7- item self-report questionnaire used to assess panic disorder severity. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from (0) none to (4) extreme. The PDSS-SR has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.92 and a testretest Person’s correlation of 0.81 (Houck et al., 2002).
•	Liebowitz Social Anxiety Scale (LSAS; Liebowitz, 1987) is a 24-item self-report questionnaire used to assess social anxiety and social avoidance severity. Questions can be divided into two subscales: (1) social situations and (2) situations in which one has to perform. Every item has to be rated twice to assess both their frequency of avoidance and to assess the anxiety that the situation evokes. Items about anxiety and avoidance are both rated on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (none) to 3 (very much) and from 0 (never) to 3 (almost always), respectively. The LSAS has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.95 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.83 (Baker, Heinrichs, Kim, Hofmann, 2001). 
•	Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ; Meyer, Miller, Metzger, & Borkovec, 1990) is used for participants with generalized anxiety disorder. The PSWQ is a 16-item self-report questionnaire used to assess worry. This questionnaire consists of four subscales: (1) occurrence, (2) intrusiveness, (3) pervasiveness and (4) other characterizing features of an individual’s experience with worry. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all typical) to 5 (very typical of me). The PSWQ has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.93 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.92 (Meyer et al., 1990). 
•	Whiteley Index (WI; Pilowski, 1967; Speckens et al., 1996) is used for patients with hypochondria. The WI is a 7-item self-report questionnaire assessing hypochondriacal worries and beliefs. Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very bad). The WI has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.73 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.66 (Hedman et al., 2015). 
•	Posttraumatic Symptom Scale (Self-Report version) (PSS-SR; Foa, Riggs, Dancu, & Rothbaum, 1997; Engelhard, Arntz, & Van den Hout, 2007) is a 17-item self-report questionnaire assessing PTSD symptoms. This questionnaire consists of 3 subscales: (1) hyperarousal, (2) re-experiencing and (3) avoidance. Items are rated on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (never) to 3 (5 times per week or more). The PSS-SR has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.92 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.83 (Foa et al., 1997). 
(3)	Adaptive and maladaptive modes (assessed with the short Schema Mode Inventory (SMI)).
•	The short Schema Mode Inventory (SMI; Young et al., 2007) is a 124-item self-report questionnaire assessing the presence of the following 14 modes: Vulnerable Child, Angry Child, Enraged Child, Impulsive Child, Undisciplined Child, Happy Child, Compliant Surrenderer, Detached Protector, Detached Self-Soother, Self-Aggrandizer, Bully and Attack, Punitive Parent, Demanding Parent, and Healthy Adult. These modes can be categorized in an adaptive adult mode (healthy adult), an adaptive child (happy child) and maladaptive modes (remaining 12 modes; Schaap, Chakhssi, & Westerhof, 2016). Items are rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never or hardly ever) to 6 (always). The SMI has a Cronbach’s alpha of 0.87 and a test-retest Person’s correlation of 0.84 (Lobberstael, 2010).
(4)	Implicit avoidance tendencies (assessed with the Approach Avoindance Task (AAT)).
•	The Approach Avoidance Task (AAT; Rinck & Becker, 2006) is used to assess implicit avoidance tendencies. In this task, participants are presented with stimuli on a computer screen and instructed to use a joystick to either pull the stimuli towards them or to push the stimuli away. Pulling the joystick will make the picture bigger (approach) while pushing will make the picture smaller (avoid). To assess avoidance tendencies, reaction times in the pull condition are compares to reaction times in the corresponding push condition. An avoidance tendency is reflected when the response time in the push condition is shorter than in the pull condition. In this study, the individual stimuli will be adjusted to the specified anxiety disorder and fears of the participant. The advantage of this task is that it is robust against social desirability (Heuer, Rinck, Becker, 2007).
registration_responses.q18.question: Not applicable.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Primary Objective: Evaluate, for each participant, the effectiveness of the SCHerp program.
Simulation Modelling Analysis (SMA) will be used to test the effectiveness of the SCHerp program for each participant. This method is developed to analyze autocorrelated time-series data with less than 30 measurements per phase and offers good protection against Type-I error while providing adequate power to detect real effects within the short time-series (Borckardt, 2006). As dependent variables (quantitative) we will use the total scores from the OQ- 45, YBOCS, PDSS, LSAS, PSWQ, WI and/or ‘PTSS klachtenschaal’ questionnaires. 

Secondary objective 1: Evaluate changes in adaptive and maladaptive schema modes during the SCHerp program.
The presence of adaptive and maladaptive schema modes will be assessed by the SMI. SMI scores will be categorized into three different scores: (1) adaptive adult mode, (2) adaptive child mode and (3) maladaptive modes. SMA will be used to analyze changes in adaptive and maladaptive schema modes throughout the therapy. All analyses are done for each participant individually. 

Secondary objective 2: Identify and generate hypotheses about periods within SCHerp
with the highest gains (i.e. strongest decline in complains).
For these analyses we make use of figures generated by the SMA of primary objective 1,
representing psychological malfunction and disorder-specific complains throughout the
therapy.
Using visual inspection, we will identify the periods within SCHerp with the highest gains
in decreasing psychological malfunction and/or disorder-specific complains. Sequentially
we will formulate hypotheses about possible underlying mechanisms, for which we can
use data from the secondary objectives as well. These hypotheses will then be tested in
further studies.

Secondary objective 3: Evaluate changes in implicit avoidance tendencies during the
SCHerp program.
Implicit avoidance tendencies are measured with the AAT and will be calculated by
subtracting the median reaction time in the pull condition from the median reaction time in
the corresponding push condition (fear-push minus fear-pull and neutral-push minus
neutral-pull). A negative value represents stronger avoidance than approach tendencies
(Heuer et al., 2007). SMA will be used to analyze changes in implicit avoidance tendencies throughout the therapy. All analyses are done for each participant individually.
